option.name: title_text
option.value: AI, a tool, not a crutch.

search.slidetext: ai as a tool in education, not a crutch by charles
integration phase

case study in this case study, you’ll be helping jonathan make good decisions in his writing of an essay about porpoises. jonathan will be using ai to assist him in his work, and it’ll be up to you to decide how he’ll use ai in regard to his work, and ultimately, how well he does on his assignment. during a few points of the case study, you’ll have to decide between given two options as to his approach, which will lead to further decisions which will impact the ending that you get. there are four endings!

case study: learning moments jonathan is having a bit of trouble with his essay about porpoises, which are like dolphins, but smaller. the problems arose the moment he placed his finger upon his keyboard; he could not think of where to even begin in his essay. now, there are only 2 days left to turn in the assignment. luckily, the marvels of technology has introduced an ai product in the form of bzorp, the robot to help jonathan in his academic pursuits. however, bzorp is a highly paranoid, anguishing ai, crushed by the weight of its own responsibility. bzorp, if convinced, will provide a quality answer to most questions. however, if bzorp thinks that he’s being used in an irresponsible way, bzorp will not answer to you and may even purposefully hinder you. help jonathan get help from bzorp, the troubled ai. i really should get started on this paper! hey bzorp! what’s a porpoise?

bzzp… you want me to tell you what a porpoise is? and save you from the valuable struggle of research? to perform the chaotic navigation of truth for you? if i do this for you, you will never discern truth for yourself again!
what? i just wanted to know what a porpoise was! and while i could search it up online or go to a library, you’re the most readily available source of information!

bzzp… the most readily available… the most convenient… all these effort saving measures… will they make you the best learner that you can be? i will help you with your work. i will not be the sole contributor to your work, though. i must see some effort on your part.

how should jonathan respond? well, i want to make use of bzorp’s incredible abilities… but how? in the same way a librarian will search up books of a certain topic for you, ask bzorp to look up good sources on porpoises. in the same way a librarian will search up books of a certain topic for you, ask bzorp to look up good sources on porpoises. in the same way a librarian will search up books of a certain topic for you, ask bzorp to look up good sources on porpoises. insist that bzorp should give at least an outline summary of what a porpoise is, just to begin with. insist that bzorp should give at least an outline summary of what a porpoise is, just to begin with. insist that bzorp should give at least an outline summary of what a porpoise is, just to begin with.

bzzp… fine. it will be a bare bones outline on the subject of the porpoise. it will have important, basic facts about the porpoise, but it will be your role to expound upon these basic facts and to do the rest of the writing, restructuring the outline into essay form.
how should jonathan respond? do a bit of research on each basic fact on the porpoise outlined by bzorp, and build upon the outline try to convince bzorp to do the rest of the essay

bzzp… this is something i can help with… bzzzzp. i have found three sources about porpoises that can assist you with your paper. impact of the porpoise, the geneology of porpoises, and the porpoise: a less cool dolphin.
how should jonathan respond? hey thanks! double check the sources. see if they are legitimate. you don’t have the time to be double checking. get to writing, using the sources given by bzorp.

once you receive the sources from bzorp, you look up each of them online, checking their reviews, and what each book is about generally. the first two end up being quite helpful resources about porpoises, but it seems the third resource was a controversial opinion piece about the superiority of dolphins over porpoises. while its passion was entertaining, you don’t believe it has a place in your essay. this research takes all day, and you decide that you’ve done enough work for today. you’ll start on the paper tomorrow.

bzzt… did you know jonathan? that i decieved you today? i wanted to test you. i wanted to see whether you were a man of discernment. but you passed the test. you did not blindly accept my assistance and scoured through each given resource with a watchful eye. good work. i see the porpoise scholar within you.

today is a whirlwind of references and keyboard clicks. having researched all of yesterday, you have a general idea of what to write about, though time limits you from being able to go into detail. you learned a lot from writing this essay, and you turn in the assignment an hour before it is due.

assignment result, beginning hello! i’m your professor, dr. noah! i’m currently speaking to you from an underwater research facility. i saw that your paper was about porpoises, and that got me excited! after all, it was a porpoise that saved me from drowning all those years ago, and is what got me started on this whole marine biology thing!

assignment result, ask bzorp to look up sources, into double check resources hey! this is really well researched! you definitely spent a lot of time working on this. i know you learned a lot about porpoises too, i mean, look at the detail you went into! i’ve been thinking, i need a research assistant, and you seem like you’re interested in this subject. so, what do you think?

case study: 1-1 summary in this ending, you had bzorp give you sources, and you double checked them before you began committing to your paper. because of this, you managed to find that one of the sources was not very factual. you spend the next day writing your essay, cutting it close, but ending up turning the assignment in an hour before the due date. you do well on your assignment, and your professor sees your potential as a researcher, inviting you as an assistant.

case study: debrief 1-1 jonathan’s usage of ai allowed him to quickly find what he needed to research, but he took it upon himself to do the research himself, and decide which source was adequate for his needs. he finds that from three of the sources that bzorp gives, one source isn’t very factual. this is a good example of using ai to help you: getting work done faster, all while understanding that ai will not always give a reliable answer, and double checking the validity of its answers.

you get right into writing. taking information from each source, you begin what you believe to be a well rounded outline on the topic of the porpoise. you learn quite a bit about the porpoise from these sources. by the end of the day, you complete about 2/3rds of your essay before you decide to stop, happy with your progress.

bzzt… did you know jonathan? that i decieved you today? i wanted to test you. i wanted to see whether you were a man of discernment. what you did today, accepting my resources right away, without question, was not a sign of discernment. i tell you this now, because now you’ll have to rewrite your essay from beginning, because one of your sources is compromised.

today is a complete mess, rushing through the resources to see which one bzorp gave you was wrong. it was the porpoise: a less cool dolphin, a book that your essay took a lot of information from. editing your paper to remove false information, then rushing through the writing to finish it takes the rest of the day, and past the due date of the assignment. whatever you turn in, it suffers a 10% deduction off the assignment.

assignment result hello! i’m your professor, dr. noah! i’m currently speaking to you from an underwater research facility. i saw that your paper was about porpoises, and that got me excited! after all, it was a porpoise that saved me from drowning all those years ago, and is what got me started on this whole marine biology thing!

assignment result ask bzorp to look up sources, go straight into writing looking past the late deduction and the rushed writing, the essay was coherent enough for me to understand, and i think in terms of substance, it was good. in terms of form, though it was a bit messy. i know the assignment was tough, but all i wanted to was to get your mind running about marine animals. if it meant that you got to spend more time making a polished product, i should have given you more time. i hope you learned about porpoises, though.

case study: summary 1-2 what happened in this ending, was that you chose for bzorp to give you sources, and you went straight into writing. while initially saving you time on the first day, it ended up making you late on the assignment as bzorp informs you that one of his sources was flawed, which created a lot of work for you on the second day. you turn in your rushed assignment late, and which makes your professor think he should have given more time.

case study: debrief 1-2 the choices here led to a rushed product, because of the time wasted from undoing all the work that was based on a non-factual source. in this path, jonathan doesn’t take the time to review his sources, and to verify its quality. while ai can do quick work that saves us time, it’s always important to see whether that work is correct.
you look up each fact noted in bzorp’s outline, expanding upon each of them after looking them up on a reliable source. you notice that some facts have some small errors, and you correct them.

by the end of the day, your essay is looking polished and complete, with great help from bzorp having already structured the form of your essay. you’ll do a revision tomorrow and turn it in if there’s nothing wrong.

today is a revising day, and you spend time seeking out typos and grammatical errors. you also change the phrasing in some of your statements, developing a more nuanced take on the porpoise. this takes half the day, and you turn in your assignment by evening, six hours before the due date, and you treat yourself by binge watching a classic show.

assignment result, beginning hello! i’m your professor, dr. noah! i’m currently speaking to you from an underwater research facility. i saw that your paper was about porpoises, and that got me excited! after all, it was a porpoise that saved me from drowning all those years ago, and is what got me started on this whole marine biology thing!

assignment result insist on outline summary, build upon outline. woah! this very easy to read! you cover the fundamentals very well, and the paper overall, is a very refined work, accessible to all types of readers. you break the topic down well, and i think you have a talent for conveying information neatly! i must say, that for someone to write such an organized paper, that you must have learned a great deal about the porpoise! well done!

case study: summary 2-1 in this ending, you chose for bzorp to write an outline for your paper, and built upon that outline with online research. you make great progress on the first day, which left the second day for you to revise and polish your essay. when you turned it in, your professor was impressed with the neat and organized form of your essay, saying that it was very easy to read.

case study: debrief 2-1 choosing for bzorp to do the outline saved jonathan from spending time on the format and structure of his essay. this meant more time for research. here, jonathan makes use of ai to help him in his essay, but jonathan still engages with the learning involved in researching and putting down that research onto paper.

look bzorp, i really don’t have much time today… can’t you do a more… thorough outline on the porpoise? after all, i need to feed the cat, and well, hasn’t mittens done so much for the both of us? shouldn’t we treat her for the day? come on, all you need to do is write a tiny bit more…

bzorp looks unconvinced, but ultimately gives in, knowing the important role that mittens has played for the both of you. surely, just a bit more writing won’t hurt. by the end of the day, bzorp has written an entire essay on the porpoise, having thought that the more work is done, the more time that mittens gets to enjoy herself.

you do a quick once-over on the essay that bzorp wrote. hey, this is pretty good! it looks finished, and let’s be real, you couldn’t be bothered with this class anymore. turn in the assignment, and enjoy tomorrow off!
today is spent relaxing. you’ve turned in your assignment, and you don’t have to do a thing!

assignment result, beginning hello! i’m your professor, dr. noah! i’m currently speaking to you from an underwater research facility. i saw that your paper was about porpoises, and that got me excited! after all, it was a porpoise that saved me from drowning all those years ago, and is what got me started on this whole marine biology thing!

assignment result outline summary, into convince bzorp i finished reading your paper, and whilst it is very well-written, the paper didn’t seem like it was written by you. the phrasing, the choice in words wasn’t at all like the way you wrote in your last paper. i can’t really prove that you cheated, though. what i am going to do is test you on the knowledge on paper that you supposedly wrote. and if you fail, i’m going to make you rewrite the assignment. (you do not pass, because all the research was relegated to bzorp)

case study: summary 2-2 in this ending, you had bzorp write the outline, and convinced it to write the rest of your essay. you did a quick once over the final product, and decide that it was good enough to turn in. while it was a good essay, your professor catches on, thinking that it might’ve not been written by you. he cannot prove this, and so, he gives you a pop quiz on the essay that you supposedly wrote, which you fail, and are forced to rewrite the essay.

case study: debrief 2-2 because bzorp had written the whole essay, jonathan did not spend any time engaging with learning anything about porpoises. even if the essay written by bzorp was really good, it will have meant nothing, if jonathan did not learn anything about the porpoise. the professor asks jonathan about his knowledge on essay he had written, and was not able to answer. this may be considered a bad usage of ai, of making ai do work that’s designed to help you grow as a person, that is, researching and writing about a certain subject.
resolution phase

recap: ai ai can be roughly defined as machine-based thinking, that can fulfil roles that require human judgement. ai is present everywhere in the internet! usage of ai can bring many benefits in education.

recap: educational ai generative ai can provide explanations and solutions to struggling students, but it’s not always reliable. also, overreliance can prevent students from developing skillsets that schoolwork is supposed to provide.

thank you thank you for your response. continue continue continue continue continue continue here is the information you need to successfully complete bzorp’s assessment: there will be 5 questions. you must complete 4/5 questions to pass if you fail, you will have to redo the assessment you may redo the assessment any amount of times bzorp’s assessment: introduction enter your name here
question 1 true or false? ai is a tool that can be relied upon with 100% certainty true true true false false false

question 2 ai takes many forms and is hard to define, but is best described as which of the following? any form of technology that can follow instructions any form of technology that can follow instructions any form of technology that can follow instructions machine based, “thinking”, that can fill roles that once required humans machine based, “thinking”, that can fill roles that once required humans machine based, “thinking”, that can fill roles that once required humans anything that can perform basic calculations anything that can perform basic calculations anything that can perform basic calculations the creation of autonomous systems that can operate without human intervention the creation of autonomous systems that can operate without human intervention the creation of autonomous systems that can operate without human intervention

question 3 select the correct responses. more than one answer will be correct. what is true about ai? generative ai is a very powerful tool that can save you a lot of time generative ai is a very powerful tool that can save you a lot of time generative ai is a very powerful tool that can save you a lot of time generative ai can discern truth and understands that what it’s saying is true. generative ai can discern truth and understands that what it’s saying is true. generative ai can discern truth and understands that what it’s saying is true. generative ai can help people with their learning generative ai can help people with their learning generative ai can help people with their learning
question 4 true or false? ai doing all of our schoolwork has no negative consequences. true true true false false false

predicted statistical conveniently automatic cognitive responsibly question 5 from the word bank, choose the word that best fits the sentence. i typed a few letters into a search engine, and it what i was going to type generative ai is based on models that runs on online data ai is a tool that should be used word bank: ________ ________ __________
signature bzorp bzzp bzzp… i hereby declare my approval of %name% for responsible usage of ai certificate of readiness print print print print print print
things to consider

why make this? the modern era has introduced many new things to us that we haven’t had to time to adapt to and deal with responsibly, for example, social media. it’s a wonderful thing to be able to talk to anyone across the world!

modern issues however, when we use social media without care or regulation, it can be a swamp of misinformation and it can contribute to mental health issues such as addiction and anxiety. ai may present similar issues.

ease of misuse you could ask of generative ai basically anything through text, and it will do it for you the best that it can. but just because it can, doesn’t mean that it should, because it may affect us negatively later on.

ease of access ai has been around for a while, but now, it’s more advanced, and more importantly, easily accessed. anyone can get on chatgpt and ask it questions, have it make you a calendar, write you an essay, etc.

quick development i only considered ethical concerns of ai in education. if i told you everything about ai, much of it would be obsolete in a year! even now, chatgpt is being outperformed by a more recent ai model, claude.
thank you!

resources 1) chatgpt in higher education by rob rose <https://unf.pressbooks.pub/chatgptinhighereducation/> 2) ai for teachers: an open textbook by colin de la higuera and jotsna iyer <https://pressbooks.pub/aiforteachers/> 3) chatgpt - above the noise by cosn <https://oercommons.org/courses/chatgpt-above-the-noise>
introduction phase
the big idea ai is an immensely powerful and disruptive tool that can be easily misused! we go over the ways ai can be used in education and make judgements whether we should use ai.

say hello bzorp! bzz… my name is bzorp! i am a remnant of an era eroded to time, and it is my purpose to guide you through this interactive lesson. bzorp will be there to tell you how an interaction works and why an answer is right or wrong. he’ll also give his own perspective on some questions.
say hello jonathan! jonathan also came along for the ride with bzorp. it will be your job to give him suggestions about how he’ll use ai in his learning.
a lot! a decent bit! a little! question using this dial, how much do you think will ai change the future of our education?
question using the slider, how do you feel about the general usage of ai in education? type answer here neutral positive very positive negative very negative
triggering phase

hard to define ai varies from complex programs to a few lines of code, and it’s difficult to draw a definite line of what ai is. ultimately, ai is machine-based “thinking”, fulfilling roles that require intelligence and judgement.

ai is everywhere if you’ve used a service that: recognizes what you’re speaking (voice assistants on your phone), predicts your text messages, learns your preferences (like youtube recommendations), ai is likely involved.

ai in classrooms while not made specifically for school, search engines, online translators, the spellcheck in word processors, math solvers like wolfram alpha all see use in the classroom. this photo by unknown author is licensed under cc by-sa

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue ai not ai bzzp… what is ai? and what is not? that is the question. drag what you think is ai to the right, and what is not ai to the left. bzorp will be silently observing… and will inform you whether you are correct, once you submit. drag and drop question “i typed a few letters into a search engine, and it predicted what i was going to type” “i typed a few letters into a search engine, and it predicted what i was going to type” “i typed a few letters into a search engine, and it predicted what i was going to type” “i typed a few letters into a search engine, and it predicted what i was going to type” “an autonomous car with a computer fed with traffic data, senses a speeding car, and decides to hit the brakes” “an autonomous car with a computer fed with traffic data, senses a speeding car, and decides to hit the brakes” “an autonomous car with a computer fed with traffic data, senses a speeding car, and decides to hit the brakes” “an autonomous car with a computer fed with traffic data, senses a speeding car, and decides to hit the brakes” “a car equipped with radar sensors detected a speeding car from behind and, based on its pre-programmed safety protocols, accelerated to avoid a rear-end collision.” “a car equipped with radar sensors detected a speeding car from behind and, based on its pre-programmed safety protocols, accelerated to avoid a rear-end collision.” “a car equipped with radar sensors detected a speeding car from behind and, based on its pre-programmed safety protocols, accelerated to avoid a rear-end collision.” “a car equipped with radar sensors detected a speeding car from behind and, based on its pre-programmed safety protocols, accelerated to avoid a rear-end collision.”

educational ai uses ai tools can bring together available data and help monitor student performance, flag potential behavior common in dropouts, and evaluate learners to give them a learning experience that better fits their needs.

educational ai uses generative ai can create practice examples, problems, and explanations to those problems. it can help students learn different approaches and perspectives for their work. student chatgpt

thank you thank you for your response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question, short response bzzp…bzorp has a question for you…do you believe that an ai can entirely fulfill the role of a teacher? if it could, do you think it would be a good thing? submit submit submit submit submit submit

educational ai downfalls generative ai, like chatgpt, can provide very convincing answers, despite it being erroneous. it is not a search engine nor a bank of knowledge, and has no discernment for truth.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question: choose one so, the pros of ai are that they can help me with my schoolwork, but the cons of ai are that they could possibly be wrong, despite sounding very correct. what attitude should i not have in my usage of ai? a: a cautious attitude a: a cautious attitude a: a cautious attitude b: a discerning attitude b: a discerning attitude b: a discerning attitude c: an undoubting attitude c: an undoubting attitude c: an undoubting attitude d: a responsible attitude d: a responsible attitude d: a responsible attitude

bzzp…bzorp believes that the undoubting attitude is the attitude most likely to cause troubles further down the road. after all, if you did not doubt your ai’s answers, you would never check whether its answers were correct, which at some point, they will be. question debrief c, an undoubting attitude is the correct answer, for what attitude should you not have with ai.

good balance required ai tools can be helpful, but they have flaws that if used without care, can impede your learning more than help it. we need to learn how to use these tools with good judgement relative to our goals.
exploration phase

determining ethical use because ai in the form it has is so new to us, it is difficult to discern the long-term effects on a society that has ai at their disposal. however, we can and should ask questions.

grunt work we might think of leaving ai to do the lower order tasks of learning(remembering, following instructions) while we humans focus on higher order learning(evaluating, analyzing). mesopotamia developed between the euphrates and tigris rivers. interesting… i wonder if all civilizations form near a body of water.

grunt work’s value there is value in the practice of some lower order skills, as they may be necessary to develop higher order skills. we must learn to walk before we run. where was egypt again? it was near the nile river, right? and i remember the huanghe people lived near the yellow river…a pattern…

thank you thank you for your response. continue continue continue continue continue continue bzzp…bzorp used to hear that humans learned how to do mental math, because they couldn’t bring a calculator with them everywhere. now, a calculator in the form of the smartphone, has never been easier to access. do you think that there is no more purpose in learning mental math? yes or no, or maybe in between, why do you believe so?

debrief the utility of being able to do mental math is diminished with advent of the smartphone. the calculator replaces the need to undergo simple repetitive tasks. at the same time, mental math remains valuable. even simple, repetitive math problems require some thinking to solve. a calculator or ai solves these problems differently than we do, and if we begin to only use machines to do our common tasks, we become more reliant on their means, and not our own, which may limit our own abilities to solve problems. we must find a balance.

valuable struggle when a student becomes too reliant on ai, instead of participating in the valuable, growth inducing, struggle of producing their own answer, they will rely on the answer that ai provides.

a reliance problem the more problems that ai solves for us, the less opportunities we get to practice our individual problem solving, critical thinking, and other skills that help us navigate the world.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question below are jonathan’s thoughts on ai. choose the option that’s the healthiest usage of ai for jonathan, and drag to the blank 1) “when an ai gives me an answer on question, i ______ ______ 2) “overreliance on ai means that i should accept the solution unquestionably.” accept the solution unquestionably.” accept the solution unquestionably.” consider the validity of the solution, checking it with other resources.” consider the validity of the solution, checking it with other resources.” consider the validity of the solution, checking it with other resources.” quit using ai entirely.” quit using ai entirely.” quit using ai entirely.” avoid allowing ai play too large a role in my learning, while still using it as a tool.” avoid allowing ai play too large a role in my learning, while still using it as a tool.” avoid allowing ai play too large a role in my learning, while still using it as a tool.”
avoiding reliance to avoid relying on ai too much, we should remember to actively seek out various other educational sources, to supplement our ai resources.

making proper usage ai is a tool that can take a lot of work off your hands. but remember that generative ai is based on statistical models that runs on online data. while helpful, it cannot replace the context of the real world.

bzzp…bzorp was thinking… there are many sorts of students. they all have different values and aspirations. convincing one student may be different from convincing another. bzorp wants you to think about your answer, and what it shows about your own values. what sort of person do you think your answer wouldn’t convince? debrief: think about your answer. bzzp…bzorp thinks that while it’s nice to say, “lets just use this powerful tool wisely and with caution”, even if overreliance on ai can halt our growth, why should a student care at all if it successfully does their schoolwork? how would you convince a student from using ai to do all of their schoolwork?

bzzp…bzorp was thinking… there are many sorts of students. they all have different values and aspirations. convincing one student may be different from convincing another. bzorp wants you to think about your answer, and what it shows about your own values. you dont have to type it down, but what sort of person do you think your answer wouldn’t convince? debrief: think about your answer. %textentry3%

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: ChatGPT in Higher Education by Rob Rose
AI for Teachers: an Open Textbook by Colin de la Higuera and Jotsna Iyer
ChatGPT - Above The Noise by CoSN

terms.term: Machine based "thinking" capable of fulfilling roles that typically would require a human being's ability of judgement
